title: [RFC 2126] permit `foo.rs` or `foo/mod.rs` to support submodules like `foo/bar.rs`

labels.name: E-mentor
labels.description: Call for participation: This issue has a mentor. Use RustcContributor::new on Zulip for discussion.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Ignoring "inline" modules like `mod foo { }`, modules currently come in one of two forms:

- Leaf modules: a `foo.rs` file is forced to be a leaf module. In particular, one cannot make a submodule in a file like `foo/bar.rs`.
- Directory modules: a `foo/mod.rs` file is a directory module. One can create submodules in files like `foo/bar.rs`.

As part of https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/44660, we plan to support either of those two forms. However, the two forms should not be usable for a single module simultaneously: in other words, you can have `foo.rs` **or** `foo/mod.rs`, but not both. (One is permitted to intermingle the two forms within a single project, however.)

Because the RFC has a number of moving parts, we wanted to feature-gate semi-independent features with distinct names. Therefore, `foo.rs` files that contain submodules can be gated under the feature name `module_flexible_submodules`.

(Note: Please limit discussion on this issue strictly to implementation concerns relative to this particular change. Policy discussion as to whether or not to make this change -- or whether to make other changes to the module system -- belong in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/44660.)
